description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the House Sparrow.
title: All About the House Sparrow

slides.title: Introduction to the House Sparrow
slides.content: The House Sparrow (Passer domesticus) is one of the world's most widespread and adaptable bird species. Originally from Europe and Asia, it has been introduced to every continent except Antarctica and is now found in urban and rural areas worldwide.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Males have a black throat, chestnut crown, and gray cap, while females are mostly brown with striped patterns.
They measure about 5-6 inches in length with a wingspan of 7-9 inches and weigh around 1 ounce.

slides.title: Social Behavior and Communication
content: House Sparrows are highly social birds that live in colonies and form flocks outside of breeding season.
They communicate with a variety of chirps, cheeps, and trills. Males use song to establish territory and attract mates.

slides.title: Diet and Urban Adaptation
content: They are opportunistic omnivores, eating seeds, grains, insects, and human food scraps.
Their success in urban environments comes from their ability to nest in buildings and eat human-provided food.

slides.title: Global Distribution and Impact
content: House Sparrows have been both beneficial (controlling insect pests) and problematic (damaging crops) to humans.
Their populations have declined in some areas due to urbanization and loss of nesting sites, making them a species of conservation concern in parts of their native range.
